posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17468550
My frame of reference is in canadabucks so bear that in mind.
>Cheap
Arab knockoffs, off-brands and department store shelf goods. Usually from $20-$60. Some deceptively good value in some duplicates if you look around, but be careful not to get scammed.
>Reasonable
Designer house (Dior, Dolce and Gabbana, Versace, Hugo Boss etc.) Eau de Toilettes mostly. Usually around $100 to $140 behind the counter in department stores or at Sephora or your local equivalent, but available much cheaper from reputable online discounters. Always buy from discounters, check the OP. Generally worth the money, will almost always have better performance than their knockoff equivalents.
>Expensive
Niche and upper-rung houses like Creed, Xerjoff, Tom Ford etc. Expect to pay <$300 for a decent sized bottle, or ~$150 for a smaller 30-50ml Eau de Parfum. Usually worth it, but only for something that you've been able to spend some time with in person. Still usually available from discounters.

>>17467312
no. roughout is done to make the boot more resistant to scuffs and abrasion. The fibers on the outside will simply brush back into position.
The downside is that it's harder to get oil out, and because it's the soft fibers out, it's easier for something pointy to begin puncturing the boot, whereas the smooth-out boots, that same pointy bit might just slide off and leave a nasty scratch.

There is no perfect boot, but I love roughout anyway.

The point of cheap boots is that, if they fail, you can buy another. As long as they don't fail you while you're out in the boonies or up on a mountain it's fiiine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17456900
First of all, you have curly hair. Secondly, only using shampoo will keep stripping all of the hydrating oils, which is what is making it so frizzy.

Use shampoo and then conditioner, only wash your hair every second night, and use a conditioning mask for 10-30min once a week. Don't rush your hair once it's dry - just run your fingers through while the conditioner is in it to separate tangles. You'll get some nice, smooth waves and curls.
You can use a leave-in oil product too if you want to go the extra mile. I out maybe a tablespoon of oil in my hair while it's soaking wet out of the shower, then leave to air dry (but it's much longer than yours, you'll figure out the perfect amount.)

>>17434337
This >>17434391 is the advice you need. Just keep in mind what type of fit you're looking for. If you're considering getting one of their slim or slim tapered fits, be honest about whether this could be a little too tight. I've owned a pair of their slim tapered jeans and wore them for a few months only to find out that I absolutely hate the fit and prefer their straight tapered fit infinitely more since it gives me workable crotch mobility and doesn't have the feminine appearance of having the thighs too tight and the calve region being loose. If you order a pair only to find out you should have gone just one size up in waist, Iron Heart's customer service is top notch. If you're american, you could order a pair from Self Edge, Iron Shop Provisions, or Division Road and not have to deal with the longer shipping times from shipping overseas to Iron Heart's HQ in the UK.

I had a pair of Momotaro jeans and they were amazing. They shrank in the wash and i gained weight so i had to get rid of them which sucked
You could buy any one of those brands and be satisfied. They're all on an extremely high level of quality. Iron Heart specifically does super heavy denim. That's their niche, but that doesn't mean the rest aren't every bit as good

like, texture? if you're looking to experiment with low effort and cost, look into bathrobe curls. takes just a little bit of time, 2 hair ties, and the tie from a robe. my hair is a similar length and what i do is spray my hair with sea salt spray after the shower, let my hair dry ~80%, then do the bathrobe curls and sleep in them. brush out a bit in the morning, or 4-8 hours depending on whether you're a morning or night shower person. if you do it right and they don't fall out, bam. you've got lovely heat-free texture

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455402
>>17455864
Yeah, it's a bad faith argument. When you say "milsurp" and ask if it can mix with TIP, you're obviously not asking if trench coats and khaki pants and desert boots are TIP, because they obviously are. You're asking if you can wear flecktarn and spetsnaz boots with a TIP fit and not look ridiculous, and the answer is generally "no." If you're going for the TIP aesthetic but like milsurp, that's fine, but save it for an appropriate situation like going hunting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17455373
I'd say I take a middle ground on this issue. Clothes that would be worn in combat 1970s-onward would clash, because combat gear from then on has been so drastically different from normal clothing. Earlier than that could possibly work, depending on the item. There are a lot of WWII items that can work with TIP clothes while still having more of an obviously military appearance than older heritage items like trench coats. Pic rel is a menswear blogger I like wearing a vintage Marine Corps service jacket with a TIP resort outfit.

All this philosophical stuff is really boring and, judging by his reply, none of your assumptions were actually correct anyways so its all irrelevant.

The problem with your whole line of thinking is that, at this point, the line of menswear has been completely severed for most guys in America. In the past, people would experiment with the kind of clothing their fathers wore, innovating within what society considered acceptable dress. Now many guys' fathers just wear t-shirts and jeans, and societal standards for everything have eroded into nothing. In that context, many young guys are going to start from scratch, without that kind of lovely effortless menswear wardrobe mindset you describe. So preaching that they should just have that instead of trying to look into particular styles for inspiration is pointless concern trolling. And again, really boring.

>>17465283
>Can someone define what's streetwear for me?
Streetwear in terms of fashion is usually comprised of fashion wear or styling related to street culture. That is, hip hop, underground culture, niche culture, art hoe culture, skateboard culture, punk aesthetic, gothic, lolita, rock aesthetic and even more recently, digital nomad life or cyberpunk aesthetic.

In essense, its a sense of styling that invokes a sense of subculture amongst large metropolitan areas or cities- something that isn't commonly seen. You could still dress in "Ivy League Prep" but if styled in a certain different manner, completely changes the style and becomes "streetwear." Essentially, the niche aspect of it all. It might be a difficult to comprehend or explain, if you have to try to understand it, you are not part of it.

As a fellow manlet I recommend going to a tailor, and trying out some different cuts. Generally speaking fit guys should go for slimmer pieces to accentuate their build. For example, a muscular guy with wide shoulders is going to look ridiculous in a sport coat with heavily padded shoulders. Also, high waisted trousers will make your legs appear longer, and wearing boots with one to two inch inserts in them will give you a good boost if you can bear them. All in all just go get your shit tailored (yes, even the casual stuff). I would avoid hats or trying to style your hair in a "tall" fashion as they both look goofy. You should, however, wear accessories that are in proportion with your size. You don't want chunky necklaces, bracelets, watches, etc.

>>17463246
I had worse scars than you, but I was able to completely get rid of them when I was 21.

Tretinoin 0.05% every night and use a CeraVe or some other good but light moisturizer in the morning. Also wash your face with a Face Wash in the morning and before bed. Wait 15 minutes and allow your face to completely dry before applying Tretinoin at night and only apply with clean hands. Make sure to not get it near your eyes and lips though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17465342
This is bad advice, for multiple reasons.
First of all, you want a cosmetologist/skin beauty specialist - they focus in aesthetic treatments, i.e. what you want to tackle scarring.
Secondly, lasers are barbaric and expensive; there's easier, cheaper, significantly less painful ways of treating scars. Look into microneedling. Thirdly, retinoin will likely fuck you up to some degree because it's an acid that messes with your skin chemistry and will have varying effects for everyone. There's a reason it's not really prescribed anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm going to give a few first impressions of some samples I bought last week, I still need to try them more , but I dont think my opinion will change much after wearing them more:

>Baccarat rouge 540

Starts overtly sweet and synthetic, but once it dries down the sweetness fades away a bit and I start feeling it metallic and medicinal. I smell a lot of iodine and blood. I can get the cotton candy that everyone talks about if I really think about it when I smell it, but for me it's just blood, iodine and bandages. And for some reason, I might be a fucking perv, but I love it and I might consider buying it.

8.5

-Secretions magnifiques

Interesting meme fragrance, I bought the sample just out of curiosity and to me it smells like milk and a dog after a rain. A female friend that tried it with me liked it and she said it was really fresh and fruity to her and that she thought she could wear it no problem. A party experience fragrance more than anything.

>jubilation XXV
Smells like incense and raisins. I had a lot do expectations but it's a boring , simple , old smelling fragrance on my nose, and the performance is not that great. For me it's a worse interlude.

5.5/10

>Interlude 53

Sweeter interlude with similar performance. It loses a bit of its appeal with that sweetness but it's 90% the same fragrance. Good but redundant

8/10

>Aventus

The pineapple is rich and crisp on the opening and the fruit smells so nice that is almost gourmandish. On the drydown all the fruits go less sweet and the smoke comes in.

It's nice but it lasts less than one hour and a half on my skin and projects almost zero. Club de nuit intense limited edition is cheaper, and arguably better. The opening is worse, way worse, but the drydown while still different from the drydown of aventus is closer to that opening.

6.5/10 , the opening is one of the best I tried, the rest is dissappointing.

Parfum is way sweeter, vanillic and boozy with the gasoline violet of the OG mixed in, the EDT is more focused on that violet DNA and leather. Think of the parfum as the sweet night flanker of the OG: not completely different, it's simply a flanker better suited for different occasions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17464803
>Xerjoff naxos

Incredibly rough opening that dries down into a really sweet dense inoffensive tobacco -honey-vanille blend. It's delicious but i wish it wasn't that sweet on the dry down, it can get a bit boring. Great performance

7.5/10

>Reflection man

One of the best white floral fragrances I've ever tried. The opening is heavenly and the dry down smells like the purest freshest jasmine you could ever smell early morning during spring. Not a fan of the peppery aspect of it, but it's really subtle, so it doesn't bother me much. Will probably get a bottle once the weather starts getting warmer.

9.5/10

>L'air du desert moroccain

I love the heart of the desert and I think this one is even better. The white florals are more present(I'm a sucked for neroli and jasmine) and the woodiness of it it's more creamy without getting sweet. On my nose it's like a room of an humid old house filled with white flowers, books and expensive wood furniture. Like waking up as a kid in your grandma's house. It's beautiful but it's not really versatile.
Just for special occasions.

9.5/10

>Molecule 01

Smells like burnt sunflower seeds and cardboard. The smell comes and goes (I guess your nose gets blind quickly ) and it lasts a lot but the scent is subtle and frankly, I don't see the point of wearing this.

5/10 because it smells nice, but it's almost not a fragrance. I haven't tried layering it yet.

>Bois imperial

Beautiful creamy woodiness on the opening that dissappears once it dries down and all you get after that is vetiver. Dissappointed because I expected something else, but it's not bad and it performs well. I smell some hints of mint, but it might be my nose.

7/10

>>17465796
For me it's as close to a perfect fragrance as it gets. It opens very similar to Layton but a bit smoother and stays liek this for a couple of minutes. Then it starts to significantly diverge. The next 2-3 hours are heavily dominated by harsh and dry woods, ouds and some animalic notes (civet supposedly). You can also pick up some rose and very faint coffee. As it dries down it starts moving closer to the original Layton with the sweeter vanilla note becoing more prominent and you can tell it's the same DNA but, as there's no apple, thankfully it never transforms into apple pie scent. Ngl - especially in the mid part - it can a bit like vinegar pringles - you wouldn't say you like it but still keep coming back for more

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: kinda new to this. is performance really affected much by weather, or is it a meme?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17466266
Winter frags can turn out to be a bit suffocating in the heat summer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17466266
To some degree, yes. Cold weather will cool your skin and cause your fragrance to not emit as much until you warm back up. Getting soaked enough from rain will dampen (figuratively and literally) your scent as it washes away. Strong, continuous wind will aerate the vapours that come off you.

Ideal conditions weather-wise are any hotter temperatures that make you feel comfortably warm - enough to help your fragrance evaporate and project more, but not so much that you're radiating. Early summer when you're in low 20s/mid to high 70s will be ideal.

With that said, seasonal frags are not a meme. Wearing heavy frags in summer daytime will be too intense and heavy; think drinking a rich hot chocolate on a summer's day.

Fasting + strength training is ideal for weight loss. Korkma, sönmez bu şafaklarda yüzen al sancak;

O benimdir, o benim milletimindir ancak.

Çatma, kurban olayım çehreni ey nazlı hilâl!
Kahraman ırkıma bir gül… ne bu şiddet bu celâl?
Sana olmaz dökülen kanlarımız sonra helâl,
Hakkıdır, Hakk’a tapan, milletimin istiklâl.

Ben ezelden beridir hür yaşadım, hür yaşarım.
Hangi çılgın bana zincir vuracakmış? Şaşarım!
Kükremiş sel gibiyim; bendimi çiğner, aşarım;
Yırtarım dağları, enginlere sığmam, taşarım.

Garb’ın âfâkını sarmışsa çelik zırhlı duvar;
Benim iman dolu göğsüm gibi serhaddim var.

"Medeniyet!" dediğin tek dişi kalmış canavar?

Arkadaş! Yurduma alçakları uğratma sakın;
Siper et gövdeni, dursun bu hayâsızca akın.
Doğacaktır sana va’dettiği günler Hakk’ın…
Kim bilir, belki yarın… belki yarından da yakın.

Bastığın yerleri "toprak!" diyerek geçme, tanı!

Sen şehîd oğlusun, incitme, yazıktır atanı;
Verme, dünyâları alsan da, bu cennet vatanı.

Kim bu cennet vatanın uğruna olmaz ki fedâ?
Şühedâ fışkıracak, toprağı sıksan şühedâ!
Cânı, cânânı, bütün varımı alsın da Hudâ,

Ruhumun senden, İlâhî, şudur ancak emeli:

Bu ezanlar-ki şehâdetleri dînin temeli-
Ebedî yurdumun üstünde benim inlemeli

O zaman vecd ile bin secde eder –varsa- taşım;
Her cerîhamdan, İlâhî, boşanıp kanlı yaşım,
Fışkırır rûh-i mücerred gibi yerden na’şım;
O zaman yükselerek Arş’a değer, belki başım.

Dalgalan sen de şafaklar gibi ey şanlı hilâl;
